short_description: Bouvet Island is an uninhabited Norwegian territory in the South Atlantic Ocean, one of the most remote islands in the world. Covered almost entirely by glaciers, this volcanic island is accessible only to scientific researchers and is not open to tourism.

health.tap_water_safety: Water sourced from glaciers and treated
alcohol_info: No commercial facilities available on the island

weather.title: Bouvet Island has a polar climate with cold temperatures year-round. The island experiences harsh weather conditions with strong winds, heavy precipitation, and temperatures rarely above freezing. The island is covered almost entirely by glaciers.

when_to_visit.title: Research Visits
when_to_visit.short_description: The island is only accessible to scientific researchers with special permits. No tourism is permitted. Access is extremely difficult due to the island's remote location, harsh weather, and lack of safe landing sites

when_to_visit.title: Weather Conditions
when_to_visit.short_description: Extreme weather conditions persist throughout the year. The island is almost entirely covered by glaciers, with only a small area of bare rock. Strong winds and heavy precipitation make access challenging

weather.best_time: Bouvet Island is not accessible to tourists. The island is only visited by scientific researchers with special permits and authorization from Norwegian authorities
